message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a urinary tract infection, and the tenderness upon palpation of the left costovertebral angle and the left flank suggest pyelonephritis. The patient is febrile, but stable, and has no signs of sepsis, so outpatient management with oral antibiotics like Levofloxacin is appropriate. Option A is too invasive and option B is unnecessary for a stable patient. Nitrofurantoin is not as effective for pyelonephritis as Levofloxacin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a urinary tract infection (UTI) and the tenderness upon palpation of the left costovertebral angle and flank suggest pyelonephritis. Levofloxacin is a recommended first-line antibiotic for UTIs and can be given on an outpatient basis. Hospitalization and abscess drainage are not necessary at this time, and Ceftriaxone is not the best choice for initial treatment of uncomplicated UTIs. Nitrofurantoin may not adequately treat pyelonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a urinary tract infection (UTI) and the tenderness upon palpation suggests a possible acute pyelonephritis. However, the patient can still be managed as an outpatient with oral antibiotics if there is no sign of systemic complications or unstable vital signs. Levofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic commonly used to treat UTIs. Option A is not necessary as the patient does not show signs of an abscess. Option B may be considered if the patient has severe/septic symptoms or complications. Option D is not the best choice as nitrofurantoin may not cover pyelonephritis and is often reserved for lower urinary tract infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a urinary tract infection, and the tenderness upon palpation of the left costovertebral angle and flank suggest a kidney infection. Levofloxacin can be used in outpatient settings for uncomplicated urinary tract infections and pyelonephritis. Hospital admission and abscess drainage are not necessary for uncomplicated UTIs. Ceftriaxone is used for more severe UTIs and Nitrofurantoin is not the best choice for pyelonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and tenderness on the left costovertebral angle and left flank suggest pyelonephritis. Levofloxacin is a recommended treatment for outpatient management of uncomplicated pyelonephritis. Option A is not appropriate without confirmed abscess, option B is not necessary for uncomplicated pyelonephritis, and option D is not recommended as a first-line treatment for pyelonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest pyelonephritis, which can be treated with oral antibiotics in low-risk patients with no complications. Levofloxacin is a commonly used antibiotic for pyelonephritis, and outpatient follow-up can be arranged. Abscess drainage and IV antibiotics may be needed in severe cases, while ceftriaxone and hospital admission are reserved for patients with unstable vital signs or signs of sepsis. Nitrofurantoin is not effective for pyelonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of urinary tract infection (UTI) with tenderness upon palpation of the left costovertebral angle and left flank, indicating pyelonephritis. Levofloxacin is a commonly used antibiotic for UTIs and can be prescribed for outpatient management. Options A and B are more aggressive treatments that suggest more severe infection, while option D is not a suitable treatment for pyelonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a urinary tract infection. The tenderness upon palpation of the left costovertebral angle and flank may indicate pyelonephritis. The patient is stable and outpatient management with Levofloxacin is appropriate. Hospital admission and abscess drainage are not warranted at this point. Ceftriaxone is usually reserved for more serious infections, and Nitrofurantoin is not the best choice for pyelonephritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and tenderness suggest a urinary tract infection. The patient has a fever and the urine test will confirm the diagnosis. The most appropriate initial management in this scenario would be outpatient treatment with an oral antibiotic such as Levofloxacin, with follow-up in case symptoms persist. Abscess drainage and IV antibiotics are not indicated in this scenario. Hospital admission may be necessary for severe cases or complications. Nitrofurantoin is a common treatment for uncomplicated urinary tract infections, but may not be appropriate in this scenario as the patient has tenderness upon palpation of the left costovertebral angle and the left flank, which may indicate a potential kidney involvement.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a urinary tract infection (UTI) with pyelonephritis. The patient also has tenderness upon palpation of the left costovertebral angle and flank, which suggests possible renal involvement. Levofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic that can be used in outpatient treatment of pyelonephritis caused by susceptible bacteria. Abscess drainage and IV antibiotics are not indicated for uncomplicated UTI. Ceftriaxone and hospital admission may be necessary in severe cases, but outpatient management should be attempted when possible. Nitrofurantoin is not appropriate for pyelonephritis, as it is not effective against the more serious upper urinary tract infections.
